pros: Angel was an amazing boss. Nice coworkers, a good mission, and cause
cons: low pay, no room for growth or recognition for work.

review_title: Great Mission, Hot Mess Infrastructurally Speaking
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Absolutely NOTHING wrong with helping, empowering, educating, and caring for the homeless women's population that afflicts Skid Row Los Angeles. Did you know 56% of unhoused women became so due to suffering from domestic violence? That's a really messed up statistic and it says so much about the patriarchy, and the precariousness of being a woman in U.S.
cons: Like so many organizations, this one suffers from too much "hooray us" vibe and not enough proper managerial infrastructure and systems. There's a revolving door of people entering and then exiting. Very top-heavy, with C-Suite easily making over $100K each while severely under-paying rest of middle management and hourly workers BADLY (i.e., at or below market rate). Frontline workers are expected to prop up the majority of operations with few secure advantages, while 'corporate' staff work from home, in the comfort of their surroundings, and have feel-good Zoom meetings about how great they are all doing and how stressful their lives are. Boo hoo. This disparity creates a worker vs manager, salary vs hourly schism that is being felt across the United States, and it's unfortunate that DWC is no exception in solving this divide for its on-site staff.

pros: Good support from staff during crises, teamwork, organization is great with emphasizing company culture.
cons: Low pay due to DHS contract

review_title: Great organization with a great mission
job_title: Case Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Employers are very supportive and encourage self care
cons: High turnover. Commute can be difficult as its in the Skid Row district of downtown Los Angeles.

pros: The mission itself is great and the women who live in the onsite housing are extremely nice. Also, the kitchen staff is wonderful and will provide delicious meals. The pros stop there really.
cons:
- The leadership is truly atrocious. They self promote from within and lack any real transparency behind decision making. 
- There is so much talk about being trauma-informed but in all honesty, there is ZERO evidence of this within the workplace. 
- HR is an absolute mess. I mean really the worst HR department I've ever seen. Problems can't get solved when they start from HR. 
- The staff turnover is horrendous. I worked there for several years and saw some positions go through 3-5 people within a couple of years. They know this is an issue but make zero effort to change it. 
- The pay isn't great. They tout that it's industry standard - don't believe them. It's not. When you ask for a raise, you'll hit a brick wall with HR. Don't even think about asking for a better title, they'll come up with 100 excuses why it's not possible at the time. 
- They won't care about any grievances you bring up. Maybe you'll get lucky with a good supervisor but C-team is too self-interested to make any changes that will actually have any positive impact.

pros: It is a Very Flexible position
cons: Can go over your end time

job_title: Case Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
-Like my coworkers

cons:

-Under Paid.

-understaffed

pros:
Incredible staff doing high quality work 
Caring and smart leadership
Progressive and intentional
cons: Incredibly difficult work and mission

job_title: Registered Nurse in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Independent RN job. Staff is supportive and flexible with scheduling
cons: The pay is not very competitive.

pros: DWC's mission to house homeless women is fantastic. The work being done really speaks for itself and the staff's dedication to the women being served is definitely seen.
cons: The only 'con' I can think of is the pay. It's really low when you look at the living cost of Los Angeles county. Needs to be raised for all staff, excluding leadership.

pros: As COVID has created an opportunity to re-evaluate the meaning of work, I am thankful for a job where I feel that I am apart of making a difference in the lives of others. This org lives out it's mission every day.
cons: This work is not for the faint of heart and is located in a part of town where people need to desire to work.

job_title: Occupational Therapist in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Very supportive work environment.
C-Suite staff are open and transparent with progress and obstacles the organization is experiencing and what plans are moving forward.
The epitome of client-centered, from frontline staff like case managers, to even property management, and the CEO.
Supervisory staff are incredibly welcoming of feedback and ideas.
cons: Changes to some processes (like payroll apps) can be pretty rocky.

pros:
- Great mission.
- High success rate at keeping women housed.
- Direct service staff that understand the complexity of homelessness and truly care (mostly).
cons:
- Lack of support to direct service/frontline staff, especially by leadership.
- Endless discussions on trauma informed care and equity, yet in reality it's not practiced or truly implemented, especially for POC. Big contributer to the toxic environment present.
- High turnover rates that continue to rise.
- Poor financial decision making process.  Especially in regards to salaries, bonuses and creating unnecessary new positions. 
- Very unbalanced workloads.
- Lack of communication /transparency between departments and from leadership, especially regarding added responsibilities, promotions and new positions created.
- Maturity, professionalism (especially in HR) and mentorship has been historically lacking and problematic.
- Consistently putting small bandages on large institutional issues. The way the agency is run is not sustainable long term, it will be a continuous cycle of chaos.
-Only 2 weeks of vacation time for the first 5 years of full time employment. The overwhelming majority staff don't last that long. Be mindful of working on Skid Row.

pros: Highly Unsafe work, HR staff in fact steal from employees. They are not accountable for what they steal. When confronted about how they stole they escalated their hostility.
cons: This job takes the joy out of helping a vulnerable population. If you’re genuinely talented and genuinely looking to help people this is not the place to work.

pros:
Good benefits
Leadership cares about lower-level employees
Good environment
Genuine care in personal work capacity and employee needs
cons: Several DWC departments are understaffed, and it leads to current employees taking on large workloads. From what I know, they try to expand as best they can, but as a nonprofit, it can be difficult.

pros:

meet fun participants
good opportunities for training
cons:

poor management
felt a bit overworked

There's a lot of hypocrisy and it forces staff to leave all the time. I don't know what it's like at other non-profits but it just feels incredibly toxic at this organization.

review_title: Good place to start your career
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The best part of working at DWC was the clients - some of the most incredible women I've ever met. There is a sense of community when you walk in the doors, and it's public knowledge that the organization is built on feminist principles (a huge plus when making the case for fair wages and having discussions about advocacy/civil rights, especially among a largely female staff and all-female client base).
cons: Salaries are on the lower side, even for a nonprofit. Turnover is high, though the benefits are decent. The workload combined with the emotional/psychological heaviness is overwhelming for staff, which isn't surprising considering the sheer number of clients that the staff works with every day and the pressure from management and/or funders to hit high annual goals. Also, programs have a tendency to expand too rapidly, without the woman-power to keep them sustainable, and the management often seems to be out of touch with direct service staff. Sadly, many department directors tend to play favorites and more than a few people have been fired for simply disagreeing with management.

review_title: Great mission, hard place to work
job_title: Development Associate in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Wonderful people, wonderful mission, good at promoting values, nice work life balance
cons: hard to work on Skid Row

pros: A very special community. Grassroots beginnings and has grown into a model for wrap-around services, permanent supportive housing, and sustainable social enterprise. Staff of fierce advocates and creative types. Working here launched my nonprofit career and were some of the best of my life. I received a lot of professional development and formed strong, transformative bonds with other staff and the women we served.
cons: Unfortunately DWC has a dark side. It's very political in comparison to the warm, welcoming culture it presents, which is sad considering all of the staff who've worked hard to contribute to that positivity. While some staff receive professional development, others are neglected or pushed out entirely. There is high turnover, and I've watched many loyal, longstanding staff members be fired for disagreeing with leadership or "underperforming" (a questionable term). Staff are initially hired due to their transferable experience and values alignment, so when they don't do well then most of the time the reason is likely poor leadership in a low-resource setting.

review_title: More proud than ever to work for DWC
pros: I appreciate how strong of a voice DWC has to raise awareness about women's homelessness locally and across the nation. This is a social movement mission driven organization, and I have never been more proud to be working in this sector to continue to fight to improve housing and healthcare conditions for women. I especially appreciate how staff at all levels are looked to as leaders in this work, and that every position is integral to meet our mission. All homeless service agencies are hiring right now, but to me, DWC’s attention to the needs of the staff (including very generous health benefits and vacation time) and the dedication to the women that we serve keep me committed to this organization above all others.
cons: Working in the Skid Row community is not for the faint of heart. It’s tough to daily see and experience the extreme poverty in this community, but it’s also what motivates me to come to work every day and strive to do better.

review_title: Good job, but not a career
pros: Ability to learn from everyone, support and help from peers, working for a great cause at an organization that has innovated many firsts in the community, value of creativity, seeing the impact an all-inclusive services/housing site has on ending homelessness, empowerment of clients
cons: Compensation and bonus structure is neither strategic nor transparent, working relationships with leadership that turn sour result in non-leadership staff being fired, a good deal of behind closed doors decision making

pros: They attract some of the brightest and dedicated staff. The mission is amazing and the way they serve women is needed in this community.
cons: There are so many politics here. Decisions made by the upper level management is not consistent, unfair, and illogical. It's no secret that the "chiefs" get bonuses while the lower level staff are barely making ends meet. There has been no steps taken to take care of staff. They overwork their staff, add a ton of responsibilities without compensation. In many cases, they try to screw you on merit increases which are a measly 1-3 percent anyway. They nickle and dime your hours if you are exempt and expect you to work weekends without giving time off. The chief level staff are incompetent and the directors are not much better. There's only one good director there. She's the best and if you don't work for her, you're screwed.

pros: I met some of the best staff.  Kind, compassionate and caring.  The work is very rewarding and the Ladies are full of resilience and strength.
cons: Some of the directors are micro-managers that know how to manage, but not how to lead.   The agency takes on too many contracts and grants and can't keep up with staffing.  Turnover has been abysmal and HR cannot keep up (mostly because of demand, low salaries and  office politics).  HR is a mess and gives favors to those they like.  Staff wellness is pathetic and salary, vacation, etc is a mess.  They say they are "trauma informed", but they don't value staff wellness  or support employees.  There have been more then one manager who has denied vacations (for excellent employees) for staff, leading to resentment and burnout.  Upper management is out of touch and focuses on parking policies, PR, printer protocols instead of treating staff right, providing ladies with services and raising salaries.

review_title: The Most Meaningful Mission I Could Ask For
pros: I couldn't ask for a more meaningful mission than ending homelessness for women. The women served by DWC are inspiring and make coming to work everyday worth it. I also appreciate that DWC is the gold standard for quality care and services and am proud to be recognized as part of the organization.
cons: Many of the women have experienced significant trauma so it can be hard to hear some of the stories, but they are also very inspiring stories of survival. I don't mind coming to work on Skid Row, it keeps me grounded in the importance of the work, but some people aren't comfortable with it.

review_title: Best job I’ve had thus far.
job_title: Community Enagagement Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: There really is no place like dwc. The participants and staff you work with are some of the best people you will meet. Which will challenge you both personally and professionally. You will get the opportunity to work with resilient, strong women and the satisfaction that you are making a difference. DWC is mission driven and truly a workplace community. Great benefits
cons: Heavy heavy  workload, but worth it. Fast paced with always a lot going on. Could pay higher wages.

pros: The participants and some staff are wonderful.  It was a very humbling experience helping the ladies find their resources.  It was touching to hear their stories and help with their needs.
cons: Upper management and the HR department do not offer support and play favorites.  It was a very hostile and unsafe work environment as there are physical fights weekly and cops being called on a daily basis.  You can not go to HR or your supervisor for support, as they will think that you can not handle the job and let you go.  If you love stress, crying, and not knowing if you will have a job the next day, by all means, apply.

review_title: Great organization to work with and a great mission
job_title: Chief Financial Officer/Chief Operating Officer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Working at DWC could not be more rewarding.  The staff is amazing!  The team works together to create a culture of warmth, dignity and community for the women.  Watching the team work with the homeless women to start the healing and recovery process is truly heartwarming.  The resiliency of the women is inspiring.
cons: Self-care is important in an environment focused on caring for others.  This isn’t really a con because of the rewarding results of your work, but is important for your wellbeing.

pros: You can see your work being put to use when you walk in the Day Center.  The ladies (participants) are mostly appreciative. It feels good to be apart of the mission to end women's homelessness.
cons: MANAGEMENT.  Rarely see managers/supervisors.  Lack of transparency. HUGE turnover rates- recently 5 people quit in 2 weeks. You can't go to HR because they can't handle sensitive information and don't know what they're doing.  People get promoted based on their time at the organization and not their skills, ability to lead, or credentials.

review_title: Great Culture and Aligned with Mission
pros: DWC is a great place to work. I have been working here for five years now. What I love best about DWC is the culture. All the employees care about the mission of DWC. The work that DWC does is showcased through the women we serve. I have seen so many women transform their lives because of the Downtown Women's Center's support. The benefits are also a great!
cons: I'm very happy at the center but if I had to choose it would be work/life balance but I think that comes with every non-profit organization.

pros: A truly unique and warm community and safe haven; vocal advocates for ending homelessness in LA; engaged and committed board; hardworking employees;  met some of the brightest people I know at this organization.
cons: Terribly poor talent development strategy; the organization proports to have a core value of feminism but does not reflect it. Rather, the org advances the systematic inequity of women of color. There is a lack of transparency in bonus and compensation philosophy; poor support for staff working in a traumatic environment.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The women that DWC serves is the reason to work here. You connect with this community instantly and want to make a difference in their lives. This place will change you for the rest of your life.
cons: The hours that you work and the money that you make is atrocious. There is no work life balance at this place. The upper management has no idea what they are doing after the CEO left in 2013. They will over work you and under appreciate you for sure and that is such a shame because the work they do is so important to these women.

pros: The mission and the women DWC serve, the beautiful facilitates!!!! I had such an amazing time with the women in the day center and in the residence. DWC get toooons of donations and gets all the $$ so the women are pretty well taken care of.
cons: Serious employee politics and turn over, I was there 1 year and saw over 15 people get fired or quit, if you are seeking employment you will see DWC is always looking for multiple employees,  terrible bosses..

pros: The best thing about working with this agency is the work you for the women! The homeless women and the women who are in permanent supportive housing are great!
cons: Too much turn over. Often times fire people with no reason. Do not try to redirect or address staff behavior.

review_title: Great Mission, Terrible Leadership and Management
pros: Your connection to the mission will be TANGIBLE. The admin floor is open to the women you serve, so you have the opportunity to form lasting, real relationships with the clients and see firsthand what good the organization can really do. Free lunch and parking doesn't hurt either, as well as a competitive health and dental plan.
cons:
Terrible salary - was getting paid $9000 LESS than I am now doing a similar position. Not much opportunity for upward mobility and A LOT of cattiness. No support for staff being bullied or harassed - I experienced attempted work sabotage by a colleague, complained to my director, and was told that that employee had been behaving like that FOR YEARS. No action taken, and I had to find ways to work around the behavior. Also, lots of young, inexperienced managers with no competency for communication or mentorship for their staff. There is an almost 50% turnover rate, and management admitted that DWC (non-C level)staff were paid an average of 20% less than comparable nonprofits. Also, their HR staff don't actually have an HR background, so while they mean well (they're really nice people, the HR staff), they can't actually help you in any concrete way if you file a complaint. 

Often saw directors and managers alike behave in unprofessional ways, like badmouthing other employees, other agencies, or even people who came in to interview for positions. No support for employees with good ideas in need of cultivating - it's a "Do it right the first time or not at all" type of environment - no room to learn, or if you ask questions, you're seen as not taking enough initiative or lazy. 

They are doing a disservice to the clients by fostering an unsafe work environment for staff. Staff leave unexpectedly, which means client relationships are cut short and that cycle is damaging! There is so "safe space" for staff to voice their opinions or concerns, despite what management might want you to believe. If you don't play the popularity game or simply keep your head down, then your days are probably numbered.

review_title: Mission-Driven organization with employees who care. Warm, friendly environment
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The opportunity to be a part of ending homelessness for women in LA. Casual attire, friendly staff, great benefits package -- include sick, vacation and flex pay.
cons: working on Skid Row can be tough at times, but you are reminded how important your work is when you walk through the doors at DWC.

pros: Well respected organization, that practices trauma resilient informed care for staff and women served, Leadership team is transparent and communicates with staff regularly. Practices shared leadership, Believes  everyone is a leader. Colleagues are smart and committed to the mission. Largest org in US exclusively serving women and everyone makes an impact
cons: Consistently busy but amazing women served and great volunteers

job_title: Resident Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Mission is humane. The work done on a daily basis positively  impacts homeless women in a real, often life-changing way. Management walks the talk fostering a self-care  organization culture.
cons: New to the job, have not experienced any negatives.

review_title: The positive mission isn't worth the therapy bills you'll need after working here
pros: 90% of the women DWC serves are really lovely humans, and some of the staff are brilliant and resilient people.
cons: The CEO and C-team will make your work life miserable. They have built a culture of hypocrisy, negligence, ineptitude, and oppression. The rampant, unchecked power, dominance, and ego starts at the top and works its way down. The culture is poison. I no longer recommend this organization for either donations or careers.

review_title: Fulfilling to work with the women who live there, but not enough staff to fulfill the needs.
pros: Great getting to know the residents who live there.
cons: Not enough staff. Often feel overworked. Staff turnover is high within 2 years.

pros: I am able to serve with purpose, work creatively and effectively.

pros: The mission of serving women experiencing homelessness is rewarding, but it will come it at the cost of your personal well-being.
cons: Lots of leadership turnover. People quit a lot. They let a bunch of really great people go and now there's not enough people working at the Center to meet the day to day needs.

pros: Being of service to the community. Fellow colleagues are amazing!

pros: A passionate company that really does make a huge difference in the womens lives.
